climbs.name: Yellow Point (aka as Green Bay Packers #17)

content.description:
Yellow Point is a system for trad similar to the red point and pink point for sport climbing.  There is green, yellow, purple and brown point.  This system was developed by Tom and myself and is used by no one else.  A yellow point has the trad gear already in place when you lead it.  We were placing bolts and need gear to keep us in line and close to the rock.

You can also lead it from the ground up without pre-place gear (green point).
content.location: This is a route done in the old Montana style of oral tradition.  With the FOB and the recent ban by the BNF and the bolts that have been vandalize at the North Rim - I won't give any details looks like for the next 18 months.  But if your a climber you can come talk to me.

content.description: Interesting, enjoyable start gets you up the heel-hookable roof. A bomber hand-sized horizontal crack above the first bolt gains you the face, which boasts slopers and underclings to the chains.
content.location:
To the right of the obvious chimney.

Descent: Abseil

content.description:
Directly to the right of

Bop 'till You Drop,

there is a nice hand-sized crack. Chain anchors in the half-cave which you can see from the ground.
content.protection:
This route is trad. Two chains on top.

(Contact Admins with beta on what gear to use)
content.location: Directly to the right of "Bop 'till You Drop" Located in the brown swath of rock to the left of the massive chimney.

content.description: This is a second pitch from the lowest set of anchors.  Roof problem.
content.protection: Since we can't bolt, use tree 40 feet back from the top. Hope we don't girdle the tree.
content.location: This is a 1990 route done in the old Montana style of oral tradition.  With the FOB and the recent ban by the BNF and the bolt that have been vandalize at the North Rim - I won't give any details looks like for the next 18 months.  But if your a climber you can come talk to me.

content.description:
Low angle route, furthest to the right at the crag. After the bolted lower section, there are either cracks to protect or a 15 foot run-out to chains.

Descent: abseil.
content.protection:
3 bolts and one or two cams in the 1.5 to 2.5 inch range should do it.

Finishes at a two chain anchor.
content.location:
Furthest right of all the routes at

Bass Creek

.

content.description:
After the second clip, you have lieback slopers past the third, then easy moves to chains in a half-cave. The chains are a bit skinny. Comfortable with a 9.6mm rope, but if you have a 10.2, you might want to walk off.

Descent: abseil or walk off. Be careful if you walk off--would suggest abseiling.
content.location: Just to the right of the leftmost chimney, this route starts in the tan section of rock at the crag.

content.description: Mixed climb up the obvious chimney.
content.protection:
One bolt before the chimney.

One bolt after the chimney.

Currently this route has no fixed anchor, prepare to build your own and walk-off.
content.location: It's the obvious chimney which splits the crag down the center.

content.description:
Work up the leftmost chimney, the top of which you should protect with a nut. The first bolt is on the left face of the crag, about 35 ft off the ground. Climb the arete past the first and second bolts, and protect the obvious down-and-to-the-right slanting crack below the third bolt with a medium sized nut. An easy mantle after the 3rd bolt gains the chains.

Descent: Abseil or walk off (walk off goes up the hill a bit, then to the left--there's a decent trail).
content.protection:
3 bolts

2 nut placements

2 chains on top
content.location: This is the first route you get to from the trail, and it uses the left face of the wall, as well as the arete.
